text: On tap at the brewery. Deep golden body. Smells a little bready. Tastes of sweet doughy malts up front and then becomes toasty and bready. Very light spicy bitterness. Finish is mostly bready and lightly sweet malt. Light body. More flavorful than the other lager I tried and just as well made.

From the tap at the brewery. A very drinkable beer-- a mild, and slightly malty lager.  Bready malt aroma with hops and some caramel malt.  Golden with a big white head, it offers a heavy quality, but keeps the crispness. Not too bitter.

Pours a clear golden orange on tap with bubbly white head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of mild herbal and earthy hops over clean lager base. Taste follows, a great lawnmower beer, and another solid lager from them.

Bottle; pours clear gold with an off white head; sweet, malty aroma with some caramel, bread, and grass hints; taste is light sweet with malt, bread, and a little caramel; finish is dry and with very little bitters and a hint of grass

Robe ambrée et limpide. La mousse tient bien. Arômes agrumes, biscuit, céréales, floral. Goût biscuit, caramel et agrumes. La texture est fluide, carbonatation fine. 
Très bonne lager.
Pours dark gold with a beautiful thick off white head. Aroma is malty and slightly metallic in a crisp way. Flavour is crisp and refreshing. Finish is slightly malty in a British bitter way.
Bottle. Clear golden orange with a thick foamy white head. Aroma of breads, grains, and grassy hops. Taste is breads, grains and mild grassiness. Average thickness and very crisp anencephaly clean.
Flaska från Total wine. Ljust kopparfärgad med beige skum. Lätt maltig doft. Maltig, ganska tråkig lager.
Nutty hay nose. Clear amber, thick head. Pecan, coffee, hay. Liight body, easy carbonation. Nice and flavorful, could pass for a vienna.

Bottle, thanks Christina! Bready malt aroma with notes of grassy hops and some caramel malt. Pours clear copper colored with a thin white head that has poor retention and mediocre lacing. Starts with bready malt and good grassy hop notes. Finishes crisp, clean and refreshing with a touch of caramel sweetness at the end. Well made lager.

Bottle.

A- Caramel, bread, malty, grains, subtle barnyard, straw.

A- Copper color, clear liquid, off white head.

T- Caramel, malty, biscuits, straw, subtle stone fruit.

P- Light body, average texture, average carbonation, balanced finish.

O- I didn?t expect to really enjoy this a whole lot after seeing it was a lager, but I was happy to try it beings it was from New Glarus. Well, NG does lagers right, why can?t they all be like this. Well balanced and while nothing stood out it was an easy drinking beer.

12oz bottle from a mix-pack. Poured a clear copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma was nice bready malt notes, very mild herbal notes. Flavor was light caramel notes, sweet bready malts. Light spicy notes. Pretty good actually.
On draft at the brewer it is a clear Amber color with a slight head. The aromaIs perfume and the taste is string bread and hints of caramel
On draft at the brewery. Pours a clear copper with an off white head. Aroma of toast. Flavors of caramel. Smooth clean finish.
Bready, grassy, not particularly flavorful but fine easy drinking sort of beer. Better options.
Not my favorite new glarus. Pretty bland for the most part. Would stick to the others.
12 ounce bottle thanks to my wife. Darkish orange. Floral. Fruit, honey, citrus. Really nice.

Bottle. It poured gold with a persistent thin white head and some lacing. Aroma is floral, grass and biscuit. The flavor includes sweet caramel. Nice finish. A nice change from my typical IPA preference.

Bottle, Ann Arbor, MI via road side truck stop somewhere in Wisconsin. Medium gold, frothy head. Bready caramel aroma. Sweet with honey, sharp citrus. A bit sweet but still one of the better lagers Ive had in a while.
Amber pour with smallish white head. Nose is grainy with some sweet. Flavor is bread with some grass. Clean finish.

Thanks Mike C-Z! Poured from 12oz bottle into tulip glass, a clear amber colour with white foam, thin but persistent head, some lace. Grainy, malty, some German-style marshmallow sweetness, subtle biscuity flavour. Some mild but pleasant oxidation, which served to smooth out any rough edges. Slight residual caramel sweetness, very light bitterness, not much hoppy aroma nor flavour. Smooth well-rounded mouthfeel. Much darker than Id expect from a classic Pilsener, this colour and flavour balance seems more like a Vienna Lager or Märzen. Medium body and carbonation, lingering malty aftertaste, less dry than I expected.

Bottle. It poured an amber color with a white head. The aroma was of grass, bread, malts and some floral notes. The taste was similar to the aroma with more grass, bread, malts and floral notes. Nice.

Pours a copper color from the bottle with a thick off white head that leaves a little lacing in he glass. Aroma is malty with a hop presence and a funky yeast on the nose. Slight bitterness initially on the tongue that turns to honey and caramel creaminess. As it goes down the taste goes to bread, biscuits and a but hoppiness. Not bad.

12 oz bottle pours a clear copper color with moderate white head but little lacing. Aroma is bready malts, biscuit, and a touch of lemon. Taste is sweet with some hops presence in the finish. Body is light to medium with average carbonation and a crisp mouthfeel. Easily drinkable, and a well-crafted pilsener, although a bit darker than usual. Solid for the style and one I keep picking up when I travel through Wisconsin.
Pours copper with an offwhite head. Aroma of caramel and biscuit. Taste follows with mild hop bitterness. Simply a well crafted lager

Brilliantly clear copper color with a small, short lived head. The aroma is bready, slightly toast malt, with very subtle hop aroma. There is some lightly toasted flavors upfront, with some lemongrass in the finish. Pretty sweet flavor throughout, with a thick mouthfeel. Too dark and sweet for the style, and without the hop character pilseners are known for.

Had way better and kinda bottom of the barrel taste. To put it frankly tasted like drinking dish soap but did taste a bit better as it warm up a bit. Guess Im more of a fan of imported beer and this one doesnt measure up.
Nice bready sweet aroma. Classic color for the style. Sweet and bubbly the malt is clean and shines with a caramel sweetness. Hint of hops to dry it out. Very well done. Simplicity at its best.

Version No. 2 - Amber in color with a tall lasting off-white head. Dry malt and grain aromas. Faint noble hops in the background. Sweet lightly toasted grains and what to me seems like some under attenuated sweetness. Seems to border on a Vienna. Not as thrilled with this one.

12oz bottle. Pours golden with a white head. The most bubbles Ive ever seen. Aroma is of grass and malt. Taste is of wheat, grass, and dry bready malt. Mouthfeel is super carbonated and light. Drinks really easy, and it isnt offensive.

A very straight forward and drinkable beer--much to my surprise, because it isnt a style that often appeals to me. Golden with a big white head, it offers a moderately rich palate and heavy quality, though not at the expense of a certain crispness. Bready, a bit sweet, not very bitter. Good, clean, drinkable. Bottle.
If you're going to drink a lager, cant go wrong with this. Mild and slightly malty with a floral aroma. Easy and refreshing but with some flavor.

Bottle, crystal clear medium amber, white head, fragile lace. Aroma is nutty lager, pale malt, yeast. Taste is sour metal, pale malt, very light fruitiness, touch of honey. Finish is clean. Palate is light, carbonation good. For a lightly hopped light lager, this is probably pretty good. Against its macro lager counterparts, I imagine its fantastic. But I dont drink those beers. As a beer I might want again, I wouldnt turn it down, but I would t choose it again either.

bottle shared. first off this is a lager and not a pilsener. medium copper orange pour with nice frothy white head. nice malty aroma with mild hop. also has a fruit essence to it. the flavor is either apple and or pear. but the malt and hop are nicely balanced with that fruity finish...I do like this one a lot.

New Glarus Two Women Lager has a thick, white head of foam, a mostly clear, amber-gold appearance, a good amount of white, suspended sediment, and not too much lacing left on the glass. The aroma is of honey, barley malt, and bread crust, and the flavor is of the same, with some background corn and mild hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium and slick, and New Glarus Two Women finishes crisp and easy drinking. RJT

Pours darker then type... light amber. Aroma is yeast, bisquit, slightly sweet. Flavor follows with a slight pepper spice addition... dry finish. Particularly nice mouth feel. Overall, a lager with some substance and character.

12oz bottle. Golden color nice foamy white head. Aromas of pears, biscuits, white flour, yeast. Flavors of crisp apples, white bread and corn. Pretty watery, medium carbonation. Good hot weather beer.

Bottle pours copper penny with a vanishing, thin head. Muted dank aromas, tasting more like a tired Vienna lager than a Pils. Overall, surprisingly underwhelming beer from an other wise great brewery.

Basic lager. Darker than most and bit heavier than most. Some grain taste but not bitter.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

3/9/15. 12oz bottle thanks to Mrs. Owls family. I didnt realize this was a new rating! Glad I checked! Clear amber pour with a nice off-white head, good lacing. Caramel aroma, toasted biscuits, toast, bready. Light flavor, bready, toasty, nutty, biscuit, a touch of tanginess. Not bad!

Nice taste. Labeled as a lager but appearance and taste go a bit in the direction of an ale from my point of view.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma sings of biscuit malts and caramels. Pours gold with a steady of white head, medium carbonation. Taste is more biscuit and malt with some nut. The palate takes a bit of zing from hints of citrus or some other tartness. Drinkable though not excellent.

Bottle poured a clear tarnished gold with a lasting white head. Aromas of toasted malt, bread and light earthiness. Palate was light to medium bodied and crisp with a dry finish. Flavors of toasted malt, light caramel and a hint of earthiness with a crisp dry finish.
bottle. Poured clear gold with a thin white head. Grainy aroma. Light body, average carbonation. Flavour is grainy, sweet with grassy hops and a metallic finish.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2015 On tap, poured into a sampler glass. The aromas are vibrant with notes of bread dough, lemon, some candy sugar, some grass, and pine cleanser late. The beer is clear, sparkling, oily and effervescent with an orange gold hue. The head is white and foamy, sudsy that leaves a good lace and a medium ring around the edges. The beer is a medium high sweet quality with a light bitter finish. Itss plenty fizzy and zippy with an oily texture but a fairly light - maybe medium light - body. Buttered toast flavored are noted initially which turns more bready by midglass. Theres a grassy and citrus zip to the finish. Its crisp, refreshing, and clean with a light astringent, grassy aftertaste.
From the bottle, color is clear golden orange in color, aroma is malty, taste is malty and crisp. Solid drinking ale.

12 oz bottle shared by MrBarleywine, thanks for the opportunity!
Slightly hazy medium golden color with a decent head. Aromas of rich sweet bready pilsner malt with hints of light fruit and extremely faint floral hops. Sweet bready maltiness without much to provide balance. Fruity flavor seems out of place in a clean lager. Easy enough to drink but needs some tweaking.
Bottle. Clean honey gold. White head. Slightly nutty, mostly straight lager. Taste is light. Easy to drink. Well executed.

A little bitter. Light in color and not much of an aroma. Not my favorite by any means from the New Glarus lineup

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle bought in southern Wisconsin. Pours a crystal clear gold with a fine white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lace on the top and sparce lacing in the side. Aroma of caramel sweetness, corn, brown sugar, and malt. Spicy hops faint in the aroma. Flavor of spicy hops right up front with some grain and corn character present. Soft and light sweetness throughout. Body is light plus with a dry finish. Overall a very clean and light beer but not quite what I expect from a pilsner.

Bottle. Thanks Katherine! Clear dark gold with a frothy off-white head that lasts on the sides. Aromas of biscuit, light fruit, caramel, spice. Flavor is toasted malt, spice, and light caramel. Medium bodied crisp with a dry end.
Beer given to me from my pal megan who went to the brewery...my mouth is kinda dumb n broke but I think its light fruit n malts

Bottle pour. Thank you Frankie. Pours a nice golden color with not much aroma. Maybe a faint malt. A sort of bready flavor with some sweet malt. This is a very different pilsener for me. Sweet flavor all throughout, but surprisingly for me, its a good sweet, which is a little more on the rare side. I really enjoyed this beer. Smooth flavor throughout with a really nice, sweet malt finish. Solid.

Thanks to Marshall Hutcheson for sharing --- Clear medium amber with a thin rim head, light streaks of lace. Taste is light caramel malt that moves through the palate to a lightly hopped finish. A simple brew, but balanced and very easy to drink.

Serving: bottle. Light amber pour. Light grain in the nose. Very clean flavor wise. Grain and grass notes. Light bitterness. Light body with a clean finish. Not quite as crisp as I would like, but still a good everyday drinker.
this is a meh beer. came from a friend so thanks jeremy. other than that its a pilsener

Medium copper brown with an inch of off white head. Smells of brown sugar, corn, caramel malt. Taste is a light caramel malt sweetness with some hay like hops, grass, earth, a little vanilla. Just a light drinkable beer that's got a good malt forward sweetness.

Mild lager aroma, pours a clear light amber with a full white head. Slightly sweet flavor, with a medium body. Im not quite sure I would classify this as a pilsener, as it doesnt have the hop notes that I would be looking for in the style. Its not a terrible beer, but not one Ill be looking for again.

On tap at New Glarus. Pours a clear golden yellow with a spongy white head that fades to moderate lacing. Aroma is light lager yeast, sweet malt and subdued hop presence. Flavor is clean and balanced bready grain, sweet corn notes, and mild floral hop bitterness. Light to medium bodied, bright carbonation, sweet fruity finish. Great to have at the source.

Deeper clear, brown gold. Molasses, damp hay, some earthiness. Touch of bitterness initially, but quickly turns into a deep round, back of the mouth sweetness. Lighter body, slightly chewy, some acidity fair amount of carbonation. Very complex, but balanced.

My first drainpour rating on this usually outstanding brewer.
Hazy Bronze. Smooth biscuit, slides right off the palate, begging for another sip. Thanks Erin.

Pours a light golden amber color with an off-white head. The smell is sour mash, biscuit, light caramel and some light fruit notes. The taste is fruity, with biscuit, light caramel harmonizing well with some grassy crispness at the end. A quite pleasant, hearty lager. Light+ body with nice carbonation. I am often down on the American versions of European brews but New Glarus has my respect.
Bottle. Golden yellow color with a white head. Sweet, fruity aroma. Taste is sticky and slightly sweet with a yeast finish.

Golden orange in color... Aroma of caramel malts, creamy malts... Flavor is biscuity, caramel, cream malts... Sweet, simple, nothing exciting, decent lager

Bottle. Ive had Two Women on multiple occasions and it is always a fresh, light, and mild-tasting lager. The hops and malt are creamy and simple, but thats what keeps it refreshing.

Smell: heavy malt. Sweet Carmel.

Overall: ok beer. Very malty. Not enough hops for me. Tastes like a lager should.

On draft at the brewery. Aroma of toasted biscuit, light malt sweetness, honey, slight dough and some fresh, herbal hop tinges. Simple but rather pleasant. Clear medium amber in color, head is fine and subsiding, some lacing present as well. Flavor profile is likewise full of toasty, biscuity, bready and lightly sweet malts, some very light fruitiness (apple, pear) and a gentle, leafy, herbal hop profile, closing with just a touch of bitterness. Clean and well-balanced with a refreshing, lightly effervescent feel, body is light-medium. Good stuff, seems right up New Glarus alley.

Fresh. That's the best word to describe this beer. The freshness comes through in a way that you can really taste the earthiness of the beer. There's a distinct malt taste that I appreciate but don't love - it almost reminds me of how hay smells in a barn. I appreciate this beer.

I had this at Norwegian Hollow. Pours gold with a white head. Taste lightly sweet, grass, grain. I thought this was good. I would drink this again.

This is classified as a pilsener on this site as of May 2014. It is a bit dark for that--more of an orange than yellow or golden--but the taste is kind of close I suppose. Id say this resembles a cheap American lager as much as anything. and a good one at that. (I am a fan of the style so do not mean for that to be a backhanded complement.) It is crisp w/ just a touch of toffee like malts w/o being thick or sweet. The carbonation borders on being too vigorous but as it is it works pretty well and helps keep the palate crisp. A slight lemony fruit not comes out in the finish, which increases as the beer warms in the glass a bit. This isnt a world beater but it is crisp and blanced, a nice choice for the summertime.
12oz bottle. Pours copper, stiff white head. Aromas yeast malt. Taste is sweet and crisp, slight bit at the back. Its a nice summer beer.

Pours a bright copper with a thin white head; sparse lacing. Nose is grainy, plenty of malt, with notes of spice and nut. Taste is sweet malt with a a nice hop bite. Slight corn and grass notes come through on the palate. Light medium body, lively carbonation. A very respectable lager.

Pours a crystal clear gold, nice white head, great lacing. Great malt flavor, clean lager yeast, german hops and a nice balance between sweetness and dryness. This is a good lager but it wasnt what I was expecting.
A pretty easy drinking lager. Bread and cereal on the nose, with just a bit of fruit. Malty and roasty on the palate. Finish is pretty clean.

Tap at The Spot. Classic noble hops, spicy, on top of a macro-ish grain bill. Filtered orange-tan body. Classic beer-beer in a lot of way, pretty insipid, but OK. Not off or bad, just an old school lager...dont think this is a Pils. No comparison to the original, which was brighter and hoppier. Some decent Munich malt depth.

Tasted from bottle. Pours a nice clear amber with thick rocky white head that really lasts. Aroma of grass, straw and hay with a little sweet smell. Taste is a grass and grains with some sweet flavors. Pretty well balanced with a nice mild bitterness throughout. Medium bodied with a crisp and effervescent mouthfeel. Definitely a good pilsner.

3/16/2012. From bottle. Golden yellow with a white head. Hoppy aromas with malt, light fruit, spices. Medium carbonation, fresh hops, good balance. Very nice.

Bottle: &nbsp Golden, a little fiery, small to moderate sudsy white head, little lacing. &nbsp Dried grass/hay/straw on the nose. &nbsp Very much the same on the tongue, light sweetness, a bit dry. &nbsp Picks up sweetness towards the end, remaining very straw/hay like. &nbsp Very clean too. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Finishes clean, semi-sweet, with straw and hay. &nbsp So clean on the exit, wow. &nbsp Great Pilsener! &nbsp Thanks Bob!
Bottle pour copper. Nose caramel and toffee malt. Minimal dank hop. Taste all malt. Mid palate trace apple fruit. Malty finish.

Pours darker than your average lager , nicr amber color to it with a crisp white head. Grassy, bready, malty, and some floral notes in the aroma. Tatse is great , nice complexity for a lager. Uncommonly used hops makes for a unique experience.

Hazy amber with an off white head. Nose is fresh hops, caramel, Earth, light florals. Easy palate, malty, caramel, and an easy finish

12 oz. bottle thanks to queenholly. Mostly clear amber color with head that slowly diminished in a pilsner glass. Nose is trances of honey, yeast and straw. Rated on 7-31-2013. This bottled beer pours a large off-white head that mostly diminished, transparent body, fair amount of lacing, slow rising carbonation, and a gold hue. The Aroma is malty, grain and musty. The Taste is that of malt, grain and a hint of hops. The Palate is smooth and this is a light-medium bodied beer. Overall, this beer is quaffable, but lacks character in that to me the flavors are bland and did not leave me wanting this beer in the future.

12 oz. bottle that I picked up in Wisconsin during my recent roadtrip to Yellowstone. Pours a mostly clear warm gold with a moderate white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace. Pleasant aroma of malt and lager yeast. The flavor is probably one of, if not the best, lagers that I have tasted. Full of flavor with ample malt, lager yeast, and notable German hops. Lager smoothness on the palate with mild-moderate hops bitterness at the finish. Medium bodied. Excellent.

An OK brew just nothing special.

Had this at Oktoberfest in New Glarus, Wisconsin, and it was on tap. Both my wife and I were blown away with the bold taste and great amber/red look. The aftertaste lingered in a refreshing way that invited another sip only after savoring the last pour for a bit. It was easy to drink and weve purchased it over and over, but on tap is the best.

Bottled. Clear deep golden to amber color, medium frothy off-white head. Color is actually quite dark for a pilsener. Aroma of spicy noble hops, slight grassy and flowery, slight sulphury note, bready malts. Soft bitter taste, some malty sweetness. Looks like they added a dash of caramel malt which gives color and sweetness. Not as dry and crisp as a pilsener should be. Bit sharpish, the alcohol of only 5% leaves a soft burn on the lips. Decent beer, but lacks a lot of pilsener qualities.

Very enjoyable offering from one of my favorite brewers. Was not expecting something this good from a country lager. Nice dark golden color. The Bohemian malt and Hallertau Mittelfrueh hops work well together. These two women have created a divine brew.

Bottle. Pours a rich amber with thin white head. Nose is mild herbs, alfalfa, caramel. Flavor is a near perfect balance of richly textured grainy malt flavors - biscuits, cracker dough, fresh barley - with a lightly fruity hop flavor followed by a brief but relatively strong note of noble hop bitterness. I would reckon this is as close as Ive had to a German or Czech artisan lager by a US brewer.
12oz bottle. Pours a clear dark orange color with a thick foamy white head. Light aroma of citrus and grain. Taste is nice and light. Light citrus, slightly spicy, and a nice malty finish.

Bottle at Drink Beer.. Help People tasting party.  Color is a deep gold with good carbonation and a nice tight head.  Aroma of grain and spicy yeast.  It has a lighter body with a crisp mouth feel.  Flavor is like a classic German Pils, with creamy grain, hop spice and a clean after taste.  Overall its well done for a Pilsener.

12oz Bottle. Was bummed to learn this wasnt the same recipe. Here, weve got a decent copper lager with a tiny bit of age on it. Fresh, clean, brassy and nicely built, but lacking a certain punch. Drinkable, with a nice rich sense of the grain bed, in the rustic tradition, bready, crackery, toasty, and warming. Otherwise, kind of ho hum.
Amber color with no head or lacing. Not much of a nose. Short finish.  Rye flavor with a bit of orange.
Draft light amber color.  Tiny head. Maybe a little floral smell. Looked like a pilsner and tasted like one too. Not my thing but if I had to drink a pilsner this would be up at the top of my list.

12 oz. split two ways. Served in a FFF curved pint glass.

A: Pours a dark yellowish color with a white head forming on the pour. It recedes to a thin ring and film. Sticky lace is left down the glass.

S: Nice malty sweetness is combined with a honey-like note. Lightly hoppy as well on the back end. Lagery yeast as well.

T: Nicely malted, a little cracked wheat with some honey notes. Lager-style yeast with a mild hop bite. Grassy in nature.

M: Light bodied with a medium high carbonation. Clean and sweet finish.

O: A great beer. I can drink a ton of these. Awesome summer beer that has great balance. Will drink again.

Serving type: bottle
Bottle. Clear amber, one finger white head. Caramel and toasty malt, slight orange. Taste is roasty toasty malt, light citrus, light yeast kick, crisp carbonation, lighter body.
Tap. Clear golden yellow. Aroma of grain and some caramel. Taste is slightly sweet. Easy to drink.

Nothing special here ... European taste...smooth lager.. European Oktoberfest ish...

Tasted on tap at Boat House in Fox Valley. Light amber with almost no head. Not much aroma. Slightly bitter, floral tasting beer. Not my cup of tea.

RBJG2. Aroma is floury, creamy, wheat. Taste nice. Bit sweet, wheaty, easy drinking. Not one of my favourite styles but I liked it.
Bottle at RBJG 2 Grand Tasting. Dark yellow colour with a white head. Sweet malt, caramel aroma. Flavour is full malt.
Bottled. Malty nose, caramel, earthy. Amber-orange color. Malty, sweet flavor, ok hops, nice balance. Nicely drinkable.
Bread and grain on the nose. Sweet malty palate with yeast and bread undertones. Finish is quite sweet. Decent brew

12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a clear nut brown with a finger of white head. Aroma is bready and yeasty with a little sour fruit. Taste is light sweet. Bready and fruity. Light bodied with a somewhat creamy texture.  Soft carbonation and a decently long finish. Overall, pretty good. I could drink this one again.

Clear golden brown pour with a nice white head. Nice lacing. Aroma is toffee, grains, a little grass, faint plastic. Taste has a really nice subtle malt sweetness with some bitterness in the finish. Very clean and crisp. Very easy to drink.

Bottle. Copper pour, off-white head, poor retention/some lace. Aroma of bready malts, soap, spicy/grassy noble hops. Taste is moderately bitter, grassy, soap, bread. Palate is dry, higher carbonation, slick mouthfeel, bitter finish. A quality pils.

Uploading old reviews that were missing comments. New Glarus should avoid making lagers. Another flavorless one, but a little heftier than Totally Naked.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours golden brown with a nice white head.  Aroma of malt, grass, and grain.  Taste is malt, grass, grain, spice, and a bit of citrus.  Very good!

Bottle, tx lew. Light copper, nice fluff.  Aroma kind of off, some corn and mustiness, and with a little cinnamon trying to make its way through.  Taste is grainy, sweet corn, airy finish.  Fizzy.  I think i am supposed to like this more but its  kind of messy and scattered.  Was looking for dry, crisp, sweet malt and hop balance perthe style.  Too sweet with not much balance.
Bottle. Light pour with a white frothy head. Cereal, light citrus and a little hops. Very smooth and refreshing.
This is how a lager is supposed to taste.  Rich, smooth taste, nails the style.

12oz bottle in a footed pilsener. Pours golden with a lacy, white head.  Aroma of pale malts, bread, a light fruitiness, and floral hops.  Flavor the same with a nice blend of everything.  Average texture.  A really nice beer for the style.

Whats consistent across everything New Glarus makes is they dont cheap out on the ingredients or flavor. Beautiful to look at, malty sweet at the start and nicely bitter on the finish. Lightweight body is a little surprising but overall this is delicious.
Pours clear honey with a sizable off-white head. Smells kinda like graham crackers and ceral. Taste has some lemon and spice. All-around kind of odd.

Bottle @ Christers. Courtesy of Jeff, Thanks ! Pours  hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of light malt, light fruity, grassy hops. Flavor is malt, straw, grassy hops. Medium body, average carbonation. 040213
Bottle. Clear amber/brown with small white head. Aroma is malt, hop and cereal. Flavour is malt, hops, little sweet, little grass and a little cereal.
Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Clear amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 040213
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet malt, caramel notes, citrus notes and hops.
Aroma of cereal and corn, a little earthy hop aroma. Slightly acidic corn flavor with some cereal. Dry and not bitter. Pours dark brown with a large foamy white head with long retention. Delicious.

Poured a light brown color that was still fairly clear. Had a fluffy white head that diminished gradually. I picked up scents of malts and yeast. The taste was malty with a little bit of spice and a little bit of citrus. Had a smooth taste that ended with a crisp, dry finish. Another fan favorite from New Glarus. I just wish the beer coming out of the tap was a little colder.

12 oz bottle. Pour is much darker than I expected even though it is only amber. Malty, floral aroma. Hints of Carmel and spice.  Clean, toasty malt flavor. Hints of Caramel.  Smooth mouthfeel. Clean finish.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2017 Pale yellow foamy head. Nice grassy, light malt aroma. Has some grassy and sweet malt flavor with hint of hop spice. Finishes with a crisp, pleasant grassy and malt flavor. Lightish body. A solid classic lager. Update: I?ve come to appreciate this beer more over time as I?ve had the chance to drink in various settings. After moving to a new house in humid, above 90 degree weather. I found this beer to hit the spot.
12 oz bottle courtesy of Joe K. Nice slightly pinkish amber color, foamy head and some lace. Nice malty aroma for a lager. Quite nice.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear pale yellow with a minimal white head. Aroma is lightly soapy and has a light, sweet maltiness. Flavor is grassy with a touch of spicy hop notes...still some sweet maltiness. Mouthfeel is light/medium with a grassy finish. Decent but not hoppy enough for my tastes...too much sweet maltiness.
caramel, amber, white foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, Enjoyed this beer Very Much, One of my go to brews for that any time occasion.

Shared by Thorpe429. Thanks Mike.

The beer is clear and golden colored with a half inch of white head that leaves sparse lacing on the glass. The aroma offers grain, light fruit, malt, biscuits - smells like a German lager. A tad sweet, refreshing, highly drinkable. A fine choice for a session beer. Light in body with appropriate carbonation.

Bottle: Clear gold with an off-white head.  Grainy, sweet malty aroma, and some yeast.  Sweet, smooth feel and a bit of grape in the aftertaste.  Another classic from NG.
Yeast, malt and fruit aroma.  Pours a yellowish/golden brown with a thin white head.  Light bodied.  Some fruit and a crisp hoppy finish.
Bottle. Pours clearish amber with an off white head. Nose/taste of mild spice, sugar cone, sweet bread and grass. Medium body. Dryish finish.

12oz bottle, thanks nuplastikk.  Crystal clear amber body topped by medium white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, bread, some lemon, light grass, spicy.  Taste is moderately sweet, bread, lemon, light spicy, berry.  Light body, some effervescence.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor. Pours deep golden with a small white head. Aroma is biscuit, malty, bread. Some slight notes of herbal and spicy hops with a touch of fruitiness. Flavor starts with the doughy bread notes, picking up more of a sweet fruitiness before a more sugary sweet finish. Medium body and a sharp carbonation.
Bottle courtesy of nuplastikk, thanks!  Bright clear golden color, small white head, solid lacing. Aroma of vegetables and straw. Taste is bitter and sour straw.

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy orange with a small frothy white head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is a corn malt and honey. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet malt and citrus flavor. Easy to drink, a good Bohemian pils from New Glarus.

Variety twelve pack from a Mobil on US12. Pours a nice amber with a slight head. Not a lot going for it in terms of smell. Tastes of malt and bread. Very smooth throughout and highly drinkable. You could pound a lot of these. Good for the style of beer that it is.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2012 12 oz bottle purchased at Woodmans Foods in Onalaska, Wisconsin.  2202 10:59 printed on neck.  The pour is a clear golden amber with visible carbonation bubbles and a crackling two inch white head.  The aroma is soft cracker malt along with a spicy herbal grassy hop character. The taste is toasted cracker malt, blended with the herbal grass and a touch of floral sweetness.  The palate is medium to light bodied, with a dry grassy herbal finish.  Not as crisp as I remember the earlier version being, though still quite tasty.

Sweet malt aroma...hint of caramel.  Clear amber color.  Amazing flavors of sweet malt, caramel, some pilsner-like bite, all nicely balanced.  Medium body with perfect carbonation.  Finishes nicely.  Outstanding

12oz. bottle:  This one pours a crystal clear lighter amber color.  There was a small off-white head that didnt linger long at all.  Just a little lacing.  The aroma is nice:  a little musty, bready, malts and biscuits.  The taste is pretty good.  Bready, some malts, touch of bitterness and dryness.  Another good beer from them!

Pale golden pour with a thick, creamy white head. The aroma is fresh and malty. Clean pils malt and a softly herbal spice nose. Clean and fresh with a great balance. Crackery and a little bit of soft hoppiness on the finish. Very clean.

Bottle. Pours clear amber with a medium fizzy off white head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is corn, grain, grass. Flavor about the same, lightly sweet, with a bit of grassy bitterness. Medium bodied and crisp.
Great lager. Dark gold. Crisp and clear. Smells of hay, tastes a bit of citrus.  Great with chocolate chip cookies!
very very boring.  tastes are plain like bread and corn with mild sweetness. weak aroma, weak color, definitely a pass.  i guess it was refreshing, but then again so is water.
bottle. golden with small head. bready with a bitter metallic finish. im not a big fan of lagers, and this one just doesnt really do it for me.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2013 Pours a clear, darker amber. Nice looking dense, creamy, medium white head, mostly lasting with good lace. Aroma is lightly toasty, carmel, fruity, light earthy/flowery hops - good character. Flavor is much the same. Bigger side of light body. LIght bitter, toasty, light fruity sweetness. Nice little bit of prickly carbonation. Smooth finish. Clean. Highly drinkable. 
Makes for delicious beer burps...  Interesting and enjoyable.

Thanks Jstax for the bottle! Pours a deep copper color with a nice foamy two finger head. Aromas are bready with touches of grass and earthy sweet malts. On the palate its smooth and chuggable with great balance between bready doughy malts and grass citrus notes leading to a clean finish with touches of bitterness. Well made pilsner... best Ive had from the US.

Sample from a 12oz bottle, thanks to Anthony. Clear golden color, thin white head leaves good lace. Sweet taste. Light corn, light hop aroma. Straw. Lightly sour. Smooth, lighter carbonation, dry texture. Medium body. A fine lager

Deep golden color with a very thin head.  Aroma of a classic lager.  Grain and Hallertau.  Mouth is smooth and pleasant.  Taste is surprisingly sweet.  Long sweet finish and very easy to drink.  Im impressed!

fizzy texture with an apple cider flavor.
clean other than the tropical fruit and strong pear esters.
mild hop bitterness with close to no hop aroma.

Pours a dark, clear, amber color, with medium head (and lots of lacing).  Aromas of wheat, grass, roast.  Crisp, clean lager taste, with slightly smoky, crisp finish.

Pours clear, light copper with a tall,off-white head.
Scent is grain, slightly musty.
Taste is malt, a bit watery, yet still rich...
a little bread.
Simple, but comfortably drinkable.

you cant feel the hops in this beer...
the beer is really malty.
average beer.

Bottle from Ridgeview Liquor in Green Bay, WI.  Light brown appearance with lacing that clings to glass.  Slightly musty floral aroma.  Pleasing mouthfeel... I was expecting it to be thin but it has a medium body thats surprisingly smooth, somewhat sticky.  Finishes quickly with minimal aftertaste.
So far the best of their line Ive had. Could use a little more hops. Overall Im impressed
From bottle from sampler pack. Pours light ruby. Flavor is carbonated, musty, and slightly bitter. Not bad, nothing special, was expecting more.

Poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass. Pours a dark gold to copper color with a large, frothy, oatmeal colored head of dense foam that leaves behind great lacing. The aroma is herbal and grassy with a carroty malt profile. Taste is light and sweet with some grassy bitterness tendencies. Its almost a vegetable type aroma. Kind of thick on the tongue while leaving behind almost not aftertaste and a super fast finish.
Mighty solid lager. Dark gold color, nice mouth feel. No corny adjunct flavors, just a clean, refreshing, uncomplicated quaffer.
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2012 This is my favorite New Glarus offering. Moderately toasty and bitter. The body is light but it goes down with an intriguing buttery feel. Its also deceptively filling.

Thanks to my friend Cari.  Pours medium brown and crystal clear with an off white head.  Nose is immediately floral hops, sweet malts, and some darker bready malt richness.  Flavor is malty sweet some darker toasted notes in there and an abundance of floral noble hops. Medium light body and low carbonation.  Easy drinking and enjoyable lager. Must have had some debittered black in there as well.

aroma is light grainy sweetness, some phenols, clean then a hint of something rotted in background.  appearance is deep copper, translucent with wispy head and devoid of lacing.  flavor is super clean graininess, fresh hay, lightly vegetal, phenols from nose long gone, sweetness bordering on cloying but overall freshness remains.
Aroma is malts, citrus and a hint of sweetness.  The flavor is citrus, malts, mild notes of fruit and a bitter/tart finish.

12oz bottle purchased at a Pick n Save outside of Milwaukee. It wasnt as cold as I would have liked for the style, but it was definitely in the drinkable temperature range. The pour was more red than I would have expected from a beer labeled as a pilsener. The aroma is also sweeter than I would have expected. The flavors are sticky sweet and a bit soapy. I was expecting a crisp dry beer. This is disappointing for a brewery that I have come to respect - Ill have to give it another try the next time Im in Milwaukee.

Pours a medium copper color with small head that quickly dissipates, leaving small lacing.  Subtle sweet toasted and cereal malt with a little hint of caramel. Mild/moderate hop flavor that is grass and floral. Hint of leather. Thin body, but not overly so, moderate carbonation. Crisp clean finish.  This a very respectable lager.

Thanks to Rogueone for sharing a bottle. The beer is a clear amber color with a medium off-white head that recedes slowly. Partial rings of lacing. The aroma is fruity and hoppy. Light-bodied with flavors of grassy, herbal hops, fruit and sweet malt. The finish is mildly bitter with a hoppy aftertaste. Decent overall.

Bottle from Woodmans in the Falls. Pours a clear copper-brown with a small white head. Some fine bubbles below the surface. Wedding dress lacing. Aroma has earthy malts and some bread. A bit of metal detected as well. Taste is of sweetish malt without much distiction. Finishes dry and fairly quickly. As a lager, ok. As a brew to have more than once, there are many better choices.

Malt aroma, not amazing 

Sweet start acidic finish

Meh
Bottle. Grainy malt aroma. Clear copper with a moderate beige head. Sweet barley malt and light grassy flavor. Light carbonated body.

Bottle pour - amber in color with thin head which leaves my presence quickly.  Aroma is moderate in strength...slightly hoppy with a solid malt presence.  Flavor is very clean and not particularly aggressive.  Light hops and bready malts are evident.  Palate is clean and this is an easy drinker...expected given the style.  Good, solid beer, while far from one of my NG favorites...
I am not huge lager fan but this one is really nice and refreshing. Slight malt flavor and light hops. Simple and nice

Poured clear dark amber into a pint glass. Nice white head that dissipates to a film with a thick ring. I get no smell worth commenting. Theres something there but its faint. Taste is malt, a little bitterness with a little honey at the finish. Clean crisp and easy to drink.

Pours a beautiful caramel color with a yellowish head. Hints of toasted hazelnuts fade rapidly to a pleasant but slightly watered down aftertaste. Not a very complex beer, but thirst quenching and pleasant none the less.
Bottle.  Sour corn/barley malt and hay aroma.  Clear amber with moderate head and nice lacing.  Grainy barley malt and lightly bitter fresh hay flavor.  Not bad but more like a standard lager.

12 oz bottle brought from Wisconsin.  Two women pours deep copper like an old penny with a medium head of fine bubbles.  Nose is sweet malt and some indeterminate hop presence.  Taste is more of the same.  Light sweet malt with just a hint of good bitter.  Body unremarkable.  Finishes clean.  Overall not very impressive.
Amber pour with a nice head. Lots of graham, a bit of spicy hops, and some dough. Clean finish, a little sweeter than expected.
Pours clear golden amber with a small white head. The aroma is light, and malty. The flavor is lighter as well, a bit of bready malt flavor, vague bitterness on a caramel malty flavored body.
Better than average lager, some sweet fruitiness. Sweet malty/fruity aroma, but not very strong. Dark golden yellow colour. Nothing too interesting here though.
Nice lager. Some fruity aromas along with light grains. Pours a strawberry blonde. Fruitt flavours up front. Nice smooth finish. Really good.

Bottle.  Rich toffee color with a small white head.  Looks very nice, and there is some lacing left on the glass.  Grassy aroma, some bread character, and something that reminds me of malt-o-meal.  The grassy hops really stand out.  Taste has caramel, grass, dough, and a great crisp finish.  Really impressed by this beer.  The aggressive hop character really helps by limiting any sweetness this beer has.
Sampled at an esbls tasting.  Whiskey brown.  A grainy aroma and flavor.  Something like maple syrup but not quite.  Decent.

Bottle from a trade, lost in my memory. Thanks, ticker! My impression, alas, seems consistent with most others in finding this to be quite a step backward from the first version. Darkish pour, looks like a Vienna more than a Bo pils. Nose is grainy and not sufficiently dry. Taste follows suit and is sort of generically malty lager-ish with just a sprinkling of pert dryness. Bummer.

12oz bottled 347th day of 2011--Dec. 12ish? from coharahawk--thank you Cole!  Clear medium amber with a half finger light beige head, fair retention.  Aroma has some sweet biscuity malts with some lightly herbal grassy hops behind.  Flavor adds some light hay, otherwise the same lightly sweet biscuit malt.  Not crazy hoppy, but enough for a nice balance (plus I didnt drink this as early as I could have).  Bitterness peaked at a 3 in the dry finish.  Light to moderate pillowy soft carbonation with a medium body.  I prefer the old version, but this is still way drinkable, and if I was in WI this could be one of my go-to summer beers.

text:
A pour into a tulip glass reveals a clear amber color, topped with a full two-fingers of fluffy and creamy white head. The head sticks around for the party with good retention and tons of lacing.

Clean and crisp. Very nice balance between bready caramelized malts, lager yeast and some hops.  Theres a little bit of both with a sweetness that may be more dominate.  Maybe just a subtle hint of honey sweetness and citrus.

Soft and subtly sweet caramel malt, nutty, toasted grain, and a hint of floral hops. The malts really pop at the front, with just a hint of sourness lingering around the edges. The hops take over in the second half, providing some acidity and just a gentle bite of bitter at the end.  Made in the style of a pilsener, there is not going to be anything to knock the socks off of most beer drinkers aside from the smoothness.  Balance, balance, balance.

This is the one weakness I could find in this beer. Fairly benign mouthfeel; it has reasonable crisp but lacks a certain flair. It also seems a little thin. Finishes clean. I would have liked a bit more carbonation and body.

Well New Glarus managed to knock me over with a feather again. Tasty, goes down quite easily, not too filling, mild kick, good representation of the style. Another fine session beer with flavor and substance. Again, me only knock would be the thin mouthfeel.
I like this beer, but it tastes exactly like the IPA with out all the hops. same feel same color.

12 ounce bottle, new release .. . Pours a medium gold yellow .. . good solid lacing .. . grain, hay, and a solid dried grass click .. . team strickland .. . a good solid session lager .. . . you know that tuesday is my night to drink beer in the alley with the guys! you knew that when we got married!!
A perfect balance of Bready Yeasts, Lemon Zest, Barley, Floral Hops and Malts make this a truly wonderful, crisp and refreshing Pilsener to drink.
Overall an enjoyable beer. Amber in color, light in taste. Could have multiple of these in the summer. Crisp and clean

Golden amber with thin off white head.  Mild caramel and mild floral aroma.  Mild caramel, malt dominant, and German hop notes. Lite bodied, nice tongue tangling zing, and mild bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a amber orange with a white head. Nose of malt some grain. The caramel malts come on too strong and eclipse the crisp hoppiness that resides underneath. Less cara and sweet malts more of that simple two row to let those floral hops speak for themselves. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark bronze with thin white head.  Strong aroma of apples and I think Im getting molasses as well.  Tasting of plums and apples, very sweet.  The plums fade near the middle and the apples come out a little more.  Finishes very crisp with a little hopiness.  If I had my own cold plate tap, I would put this through it and die happy.
A very nice pilsner. Aromatic, smooth, then a pleasing kind of pilsner finish.
Nice head. Crystal clear. Classic lager nose bready with malt in the background and some hops. Crisp and malty flavor with mild hops. Very clean flavor. Some bitterness on the finish.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2012 Aroma has a certain breadiness to it with some very mild spiced overtones.

Appearance is sort of a deep copper.  Its a nice off white head to start but falls off quickly.

Its medium bodied with a medium texture that sticks slightly to the glass.  Carbonation dissipates fast and leaves just a slight lacing down the glass.  Slightly bitter on the finish.

Not a bad lager, but I wouldnt put this in my top 5 New Glarus brews.  If it wasnt in the variety pack, I wouldnt seek it out on its own.

Re-rate:  I tried it again just to make sure I wasnt selling it short.  Unfortunately I had the opposite reaction and lowered some of my scores.  Maybe I just dont enjoy style and that factors into my rating.  But for me, this just tasted like a run of the mill lager.  Nothing special and Ive had much better.  Its too bad.  Sounds like the few years prior might have been a better beer according to people on here.

Big thanks to BeerFMAndy for getting a nice box of New Glarus out to me. Served in a New Glarus tasting glass.

Pours a somewhat-dark golden color with a thin white head and a bit of lacing on the way down. The nose carries some bready malt and a very faint hop presence. I pegged this as a non-adjunct American lager, and was disappointed to see if called a pilsner. The hop presence in this is quite subdued, and instead theres a bit of light bready malt. Body is a bit too heavy for a pilsner without the refreshing dryness.

Thanks to JMack for the bottle. Pours a nutty brown with a thick white head. Big noble hops, earthy and a touch of sweetness in the aroma. Taste is smooth big malt, clean with a touch noble hop bitterness. Well balanced and very tasty, excellent lager.

12 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo.  Pours a clear copper color with a small off white head.  The aroma has caramel and bready malts, mild herbal notes and light touches of fruit, spicy hops and yeast.  The flavor has a moderately sweet caramel malt backbone with light fruitiness, yeast and fruits.  The flavor seems to fall off a bit at the finish.  Not too bad.
Bottle. Pour is red orange with thick clearish body. Small head and lace. Aromas of wood, soy, light malts. Taste is an asian zesty flavor with some spicy hops. Smooth finish. Good lager.

Now thats a session lager!  12oz bottle from Festival Foods in Fond du Lac, WI.  Pours clear, rich dark amber (nearly bronze) with a moderate fizzy white head.  Aroma is fresh biscuit dough with a touch of spicy hops layered over caramel.  Flavors match, with doughy malt front and center, fading through to a faint but nicely-balanced sweet and spicy hop finish.  Infinitely consumable, Im not sure how the 2010 version could have been much better for the style!

12oz bottle. Rating #150. Clear darkish amber color, not what I was expecting at all. Clean and bready, rich and caramelly with a light raisin aroma in the finish. Sweet and caramelly flavor, more light fruits with a malty caramel finish. Nice stuff. (2267)

text: Pours a great, deep color.  The taste is pleasant and not too strong.  Not much head, but a great beer.

Amazingly drinkable and tasty lager. Pours copper with a small head.  Light biscuity malt with a gentle but refreshing hop aroma.  Light to medium body with a slight malt start and gentle bitter finish  A great example of a session beer that doesnt have to assault your taste buds to be good.

Very smooth deep amber beer.  Grainy.  Lightly hopped.  Clean palate, light body.   Like all New Glarus beers that I have sampled so far, carbonation is lively.
Pretty decent for a lager, in fact I am actually impressed to a degree. Although I am drunk as hell.
